body.p: The Eighth Anniversary Meeting of the Jewish Foster

Another circle of months is perfected since our
last anniversary, and trusting to enlist your earnest
interest and reawaken your sympathies we present to
the friends and members of “The Jewish Foster Home Sy”, the
Eighth Annual record of its progress, condition and
requirements. To relieve distress, to rescue innocence
from temptation, to inculcate upon the minds of those
committed to our charge a knowledge of our holy
faith, and in so doing foster in their hearts a love and
veneration for its sacred teachings & obligations and
prepare them for all moral and social responsibilities
that may await them, are the objects and aim of the
Institution,—considerations that appeal equally to our
pride and principles, and constitute the superstructure
that can be perfected only by the combined efforts
and influence of our people in giving aid, strength
and substantial permanency to its foundation—
as unity is the watch-word of our nation, so should
unanimity be the main spring of our associated
charities. A noble bridge spanning one of the
beautiful rivers of our own state becomes more secure
more stable in proportion to the pressure brought
to bear upon it—beautiful would be our record
if in our emergencies our friends would willingly so

exert their energies and capabilities that we might
feel the assurance of a firmer more enduring
establishment. The increased rates of provisions &c
tell seriously & ominously upon our means—the
detailed account of the Treasurer will give the financial
state of the Society—we have been obliged to dispose
of ? stock, which was effected

Our receipts inclusive of donations and subscriptions
& a balance of last year of 361.19 amount to $2260.642499.45, the expenditures of the Society to #2460.64
balance 245.29 Owing to the unfortunate state of our Country,
the subscription from our Southern friends is very limited—
To our Triennial Subscribers we return our cordial
thanks—, their obligations expire with this year,—
it has been suggested that in view of our present
need, many would be induced to continue their
subscriptions for a renewed limited period—we
respectfully present the matter for your consideration.

Since our last meeting children have been admitted
into the Home—three have been removed their parents being
enabled to maintain them, —one has been indentured to a
trade—Another has been called from our band under
sad circumstances—from the midst of the youthful
family of the 'Home', a bright little boy of nine years of
age was summoned to his Heavenly home—he died
suddenly from internal injuries received from a fall,
while on his way to school, and notwithstanding
the most careful attendance of the physician and

the motherly kindness of the matron, his case proved
beyond the reach of all human skill—His The funeral
arrangements were conducted by his relatives and members
of the Board Home,—the Rev. S. Morais addressed the children
impressively on the occasion, when with the usual last
rites, his remains were interred in the Federal St
cemetery,—the lot was presented by the Congregation Mickve
Israel. Since our organization five boys have
attained their religious majority, which in each case
has been solemnized in synagogue and joyfully
celebrated at the Home—it has been the privilege of the
young Bar-mitzvah to invite all his seniors who may
have left the Institution to enter upon life's duties, to
celebrate the day with him at the Home—the affectionate
intimacy existing between those whose paths are now
cast in separate places, which these re-unions tend
to strengthen, will we hope be life-long and useful
in its consequences.* All accounts of the boys who
have been indentured are entirely satisfactory—the
eldest now in his 18th year, appropriates a regular
monthly allowance to his mother—his term of apprenticeship
expired some time since, but he still remains with
his employer from whom he receives the kindest
paternal care. Two boys yet remain in the Institution
who are of a suitable age to be placed to a trade, as
soon as an eligible situation can be secured for
them. We are happy here to express our warm

appreciation of the ability and fidelity of the matron
she exerts a most happyfying influence upon the
children so intimately dependent upon her.

We regret having been obliged to dispense with the
useful services of Mrs. M. Dormitzer as a manager of the
Society—, the Board cordially unite in an expression
of kind wishes for her perfect restoration to health.

A legacy of $50 has been bequested to the Society from
the benevolence of Mrs. B. Spanier, deceased. Twenty dollars
were realized by the disposal of a tasteful ornamental
sofa-cushion, presented by Mrs. J. L. Filerance.

To Dr. A.C. Bournonville we would express our reserved
obligations—he is unwearying in his attention, and
unremitting in his kindness. From the German Ladies
Sewing Society we received a handsome donation of
clothing—we are extremely indebted for their contributions
during this and the preceding year. We would also
make acknowledgments to Dr. D. Roberts, Dental Surgeon, to the
Hebrew Education Sy, and to all friends from whom we have
received gifts or services. To Mr Alfred A. Allen, Conveyances, we
are indebted for gratuitous services and disinterested
exertions? in behalf of the Home.

We earnestly ask the protection of the Most High
trusting that that His kind Providence may shield
& bless us now & evermore.

* For instruction & preparation of two of the boys
for the reading of their Bar Mitzvah portions, we
are deeply indebted to Miss S. C. Peixotta, who kindly
and opportunely volunteered her efficient services.
